author: TomPegden
title: TomPegden published BREXIT: Small firms demand EU funding be replaced to avoid...
text:
Comments (0) 
The Federation of Small Businesses is demanding that billions of pounds in EU funding for small firms is replaced to avoid a post-Brexit slowdown. 
The business support group said the next Government must seize the opportunities being created and radically reform England's business support landscape. 
It wants a streamlined Growth Fund for England before the Brexit process is completed, bringing 
together a domestic replacement for EU funding and the Single Local Growth Fund. 
It said while the EU has promised Â£3.6 billion to help small UK firms up to 2020, there is currently no regional development spend budgeted at the national level beyond 2021. 
Read more: MSV takeover of Donington Park race track stalls 
County FSB development manager Jennifer Thomas said: "If the next Government is serious about developing an industrial strategy that delivers growth and prosperity, funding dedicated to small business support and access to finance after we leave the EU must be replaced as a matter of urgency." 
"We have no shortage of FSB members informing us that EU-funded support is a vital lifeline.", but we also hear loud and clear from local members that the process can be laborious and over-complicated, and take far too much time out of the business. 
"Brexit gives us an unprecedented opportunity for reforming these processes and it's essential that small businesses are consulted and listened to, to make sure their needs are met and funding goes to where it can make the biggest impact on our economy."
